Re ''Not Your Mom's Prom?,'' by Kate Stone Lombardi (Generations, May 27):

I was dismayed on Memorial Day weekend to read that only in the 1970s, during and after the Vietnam War, did high school students feel a certain sadness about the war and trim down their prom excesses. Wow! That is really sending the wrong message.

Even in the most privileged of communities -- my hometown, Greenwich -- prom night is a more laid-back affair. There are only a few limos, and many private schools have bans on such grandiose extras. Parties before and after are discouraged, in order to discourage drinking and driving.

I hope that the parent-driven prom extravagances can be slimmed down to honor our soldiers fighting in Iraq and Afghanistan. The lavish preparations described in Ms. Lombardi's article are, to say the least, very disheartening.
